title: 112_hr2956
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fair and Equitable Postal Service Access Act" and includes amendments to post office closure or consolidation procedures. The "Fair and Equitable Postal Service Access Act" amends Section 404(d) of title 39, United States Code, to include considerations for post office closures or consolidations, such as impact on access to services for elderly, economically disadvantaged, individuals with limited mobility, and those without reliable internet access. It also requires reporting on money-order transactions, international mail volume, and customer numbers at post offices. The "Fair and Equitable Postal Service Access Act" amends Section 404(d) of title 39, United States Code, to include considerations for post office closures or consolidations. Any determination to close or consolidate a post office must be in writing and include findings with respect to required considerations. The Postal Service shall not close or consolidate a post office if it would negatively impact individuals in the community. The "Fair and Equitable Postal Service Access Act" amends Section 404(d) of title 39, United States Code, to include considerations for post office closures or consolidations. An individual is considered 'economically disadvantaged' if at least 60 percent of households in their community have children eligible for free or reduced-price lunches. The term 'elderly' refers to individuals aged 65 or older. The definition of 'post office' includes branch post offices and post office stations. Limited mobility of an individual is determined based on their community. The accessibility of public transportation and the rate of highway motor vehicle ownership in an individual's community are factors used to determine their level of mobility. This information is crucial in assessing whether an individual is economically disadvantaged or elderly. The Postal Service will use the Internet Use Supplement from the Current Population Survey to assess internet access for individuals. They may also utilize data from local, state, or federal governments to gather statistical information for specific groups. These amendments apply to post offices slated for closure or consolidation under section 404(d) of title 39, United States Code. The Postal Service may use the Internet Use Supplement from the Current Population Survey to evaluate internet access. Amendments apply to post offices set for closure or consolidation under section 404(d) of title 39, United States Code. Additionally, the Postal Service may request an advisory opinion from the Postal Regulatory Commission for proposals that change postal services nationwide.
